High blood pressure is a chronic disease where the pressure of the blood against the walls of the arteries is too high. If blood pressure is elevated for a long time, it will put a lot of pressure on the heart, becoming the cause of many serious cardiovascular complications such as: cerebrovascular accident, heart failure, coronary heart disease, myocardial infarction. heart,... However, you can absolutely prevent or treat high blood pressure. Early detection and choosing a heart-healthy lifestyle can prevent high blood pressure from damaging your health.

Blood pressure is the pressure exerted on the walls of the arteries to bring blood from the heart to the tissues of the body. Blood pressure is created by the force of contraction of the heart muscle and the resistance of the artery walls. Systolic blood pressure, or systolic blood pressure, is the highest blood pressure in the blood vessels. Systolic blood pressure is the force of blood on the arteries when the heart contracts (the heart is in contraction). Indicated as the greater or upper number in the blood pressure reading. Systolic blood pressure usually varies with age, usually between 90 and 140 mmHg. Diastolic pressure, also known as diastolic blood pressure, is the lowest blood pressure in the blood vessels that occurs between contractions of the heart. Diastolic pressure is the force of blood against the artery walls when the heart relaxes (the heart muscle is relaxed). Indicated as the lower or lower number in the blood pressure reading. Diastolic blood pressure ranges from 50 to 90 mmHg.
How to determine high blood pressure?

Although it can cause many dangerous complications, the symptoms of high blood pressure are not obvious. The patient may have one or more of the following:
 ● Breathe shallowly.
 ● Headache, dizziness, tinnitus, loss of balance.
 ● Nosebleed.
 ● Chest pain, heart palpitations, palpitations, shortness of breath.
 ● Dizzy.
 ● Eyes blurred.
 ● Red face, nausea, vomiting.
 ● Hematuria.
 ● Insomnia.
 Because there is no one symptom that is considered characteristic of the disease, the most accurate way to know if you have this disease is to have your blood pressure checked regularly at a medical facility or use a blood pressure monitor at home.
Table to determine the levels of blood pressure
To determine your blood pressure numbers, you can see the blood pressure category below:

A blood pressure reading below 120/80 mmHg is considered within the normal range. If your results fall into this category, stick to good heart-healthy habits like eating a balanced diet and exercising regularly.

The systolic reading is between 120 and 129 mmHg and the diastolic reading is less than 80 mmHg. During this stage, doctors usually don\'t treat high blood pressure with medication. Instead, doctors give guidelines that encourage lifestyle changes to improve health.
Blood pressure always hovers around 140/90 mmHg or higher. At this stage of high blood pressure, doctors may prescribe medication in combination with changes in eating and living habits.
Blood pressure always fluctuates between 130-139 systolic or 80-89 mmHg diastolic. At this stage, you should change to a healthier lifestyle and consider taking more blood pressure medications.

This stage of hypertension requires medical attention. If your blood pressure reading suddenly exceeds 180/120 mmHg, wait five minutes and then check your blood pressure again. If your readings are still abnormally high, you need to contact your doctor or go to the nearest medical facility to check.
Factors that increase the risk of high blood pressure

Anyone can develop high blood pressure, but there are several factors that can increase your risk: 
• Life style 
Some lifestyle habits can increase the risk of high blood pressure, such as inactivity, high use of stimulants, stress and anxiety, a diet too high in salt... 
• Family history 
Many observational studies show that children born in families with parents with high blood pressure in particular or other cardiovascular diseases in general will have a higher risk of having it than the general population. 
• Age/gender 
Age is an unmodifiable risk factor for hypertension. However, knowing how to limit other factors that increase blood pressure will help stabilize blood pressure sustainably over time. Before age 55, men are more likely to develop high blood pressure than women. After age 55, women are more likely to develop it than men. 
• Race 
According to many studies, high blood pressure is more common in African-American adults.
• Weight 
People who are overweight or obese are more likely to have high blood pressure than those who have effective weight control 
• There are also some other factors such as side effects of drugs during treatment, comorbidities, improper blood pressure measurement...
Heart rate: The heart beats abnormally fast, causing the patient to often feel palpitations.

Headache: Increased pressure in the walls of the blood vessels affects the pressure inside the cranium, leading to headaches that cannot be relieved even with medication. In some cases, the pain can increase with intense intensity, the patient needs immediate emergency assistance.

Blushing: This phenomenon occurs when the blood vessels in the face dilate. However, this sign is not a typical symptom, because the blushing reaction can be caused by many different causes such as hot, cold weather, spicy food, etc. However, you should not be subjective. as this can be a warning sign of abnormal blood pressure readings.

Vision: Increased pressure can damage blood vessels in the eye. The most common complications are retinal diseases, more serious can cause patients to lose vision completely. In addition, the optic nerve can also be affected if the high blood pressure persists.
Some other symptoms: shallow breathing, nausea, shortness of breath, insomnia, etc.
What are the dangerous complications that high blood pressure can cause?
Heart failure: The heart has to work too hard to pump blood to the body, causing the heart to enlarge and weaken over time.
Kidney failure: The blood vessels in the kidneys narrow, causing kidney failure.

Stroke, myocardial infarction: The risk of atherosclerosis in people with high blood pressure is very high. The hardening of the blood vessel wall, the plaque attached to the blood vessel wall can peel off and drift away, leading to blockage of smaller blood vessels causing stroke, heart attack.
Aneurysm: High blood pressure can cause aneurysms when ruptured aneurysms will cause bleeding, the most dangerous is cerebral hemorrhage, causing high mortality.
Brain complications: Brain hemorrhage, cerebral infarction, memory loss…

Metabolic syndrome: Metabolic disorders of the body such as sugar metabolism disorders causing diabetes, fat metabolism disorders causing hyperlipidemia, protein metabolism disorders causing increased uric acid leading to gout…
Retinal hemorrhage: Blood vessels in the eye burst, causing eye pain, blurred vision, and more dangerously, blindness.
High blood pressure is also a risk of causing glaucoma, also known as a headache (severe headache, eye pain, blurred vision, if not treated promptly, it will lead to blindness).

DASH (short for Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension) is a healthy diet designed to help treat high blood pressure or prevent it. It\'s a diet based on studies funded by the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI). The DASH diet encourages you to reduce salt in your diet and eat foods rich in nutrients that help lower blood pressure, such as potassium, calcium, and magnesium.

Proper protein supplementation: should only use low-fat meats, seafood, low-fat or fat-free milk, ... or some plant proteins such as soybeans, peanuts, chia seeds, ... to limit the amount of cholesterol and acid. unhealthy saturated fat such as fat, animal organs, packaged and processed foods, etc.

Fiber: you should eat a lot of dark green vegetables such as water spinach, kale, spinach, etc. In addition to vitamins and antioxidants, these foods also contain a lot of Potassium, Magnesium, which is very good for your digital health. abnormally high blood pressure measurement.
Starch: Replace refined starch with whole grains such as brown rice, oats, glutinous rice, etc.
Limit foods high in saturated fat. These foods include fatty meats, full-fat dairy products, and tropical oils like coconut, palm kernel, and palm oil.

Limit salt: Eating a lot of salt makes the body need to replenish water, increasing pressure on blood vessels. Therefore, only light dishes should be processed, not a lot of spices (salt, fish sauce, soup powder, ...).
Some other notes: drink enough water, give up the habit of using coffee, alcohol, tobacco, should lose weight if the body is obese, ...
Following the DASH eating plan and maintaining a healthy lifestyle at the same time will help lower your blood pressure.

Pregnancy-Induced Hypertension is an increase in blood pressure that occurs after the 20th week of pregnancy and returns to normal 6 weeks after delivery. High blood pressure in pregnancy is mild at about 140-159/90-109 mmHg, severe when ≥160/100 mmHg.
2. Causes of high blood pressure in pregnant women
The disease can be caused by the following main causes: "
Nutrition during pregnancy is not scientific, pregnant women eat too salty;
Pregnant women are not physically active, do not take care of the pregnancy properly;
Sudden weather changes, too hot or too cold;
Pregnant women with diabetes or related diseases that lead to high blood pressure complications during pregnancy.
3. Know the symptoms of high blood pressure during pregnancy
Common signs of high blood pressure in pregnant women appear in the second half of pregnancy include:
Visual disturbances (blurred vision, double vision, transient loss of vision,...);
Severe headache, epigastric pain, retrosternal chest pain and shortness of breath.
4. How to prevent high blood pressure in pregnancy?

Doctors said that if gestational hypertension is not detected early and treated promptly, it will lead to many dangerous complications for both mother and baby. To avoid unfortunate incidents, before planning a pregnancy, women should note the following issues:
Avoid pregnancy and childbirth at an advanced age;
Overweight women need a weight loss plan before pregnancy;

Follow a healthy diet, eat lots of fruits and vegetables, etc. to reduce the risk of gestational diabetes. If you already have diabetes, pregnant women need to control their blood sugar well before and during pregnancy;

Exercise in moderation before and during pregnancy under the guidance of your doctor. Pregnant women diagnosed with pre-eclampsia need gentle exercise, and it is not recommended to stay in bed for a long time.

Strength training through sports activities is an indispensable part of the process of lifestyle change and treatment of hypertension. However, depending on the stage, patients with hypertension should pursue some appropriate exercises to balance their blood pressure levels.
Normally, it takes 2-3 months of regular exercise for blood pressure to change positively. So you need to persevere in practice and avoid discouragement.
During stage 1 and 2 hypertension, you can combine and alternate many different exercises to avoid boredom.
Going to the park or finding friends to practice with is an effective measure for people with high blood pressure, while helping you keep your spirits up and enjoy social life.
Warming up before exercise and relaxing after exercise play an important role, helping you avoid injury and giving your body time to balance blood pressure.
Always breathe evenly, breathe deeply while exercising. Holding your breath or breathing irregularly can cause your blood pressure to rise and cause muscle pain.
